Get started

get-started.Rmd
library(mintyr)

split_cv 

dt_split <- w2l_split(data = iris, cols2l = 1:2, by = "Species")
split_cv(split_dt = dt_split, v = 3, repeats = 2)
#> $Sepal.Length_setosa
#>                       splits      id    id2              train
#>                       <list>  <char> <char>             <list>
#> 1: <vfold_split[33x17x50x3]> Repeat1  Fold1 <data.table[33x3]>
#> 2: <vfold_split[33x17x50x3]> Repeat1  Fold2 <data.table[33x3]>
#> 3: <vfold_split[34x16x50x3]> Repeat1  Fold3 <data.table[34x3]>
#> 4: <vfold_split[33x17x50x3]> Repeat2  Fold1 <data.table[33x3]>
#> 5: <vfold_split[33x17x50x3]> Repeat2  Fold2 <data.table[33x3]>
#> 6: <vfold_split[34x16x50x3]> Repeat2  Fold3 <data.table[34x3]>

c2p_nest 

col_names <- c("Sepal.Length", "Sepal.Width", "Petal.Length")
c2p_nest(iris, cols2bind = col_names, pairs_n = 2, sep = "&")
#>                        pairs                data
#>                       <char>              <list>
#> 1:  Sepal.Length&Sepal.Width <data.table[150x4]>
#> 2: Sepal.Length&Petal.Length <data.table[150x4]>
#> 3:  Sepal.Width&Petal.Length <data.table[150x4]>
c2p_nest(iris, cols2bind = col_names, pairs_n = 2, by = "Species")
#>                        pairs    Species               data
#>                       <char>     <fctr>             <list>
#> 1:  Sepal.Length-Sepal.Width     setosa <data.table[50x3]>
#> 2:  Sepal.Length-Sepal.Width versicolor <data.table[50x3]>
#> 3:  Sepal.Length-Sepal.Width  virginica <data.table[50x3]>
#> 4: Sepal.Length-Petal.Length     setosa <data.table[50x3]>
#> 5: Sepal.Length-Petal.Length versicolor <data.table[50x3]>
#> 6: Sepal.Length-Petal.Length  virginica <data.table[50x3]>
#> 7:  Sepal.Width-Petal.Length     setosa <data.table[50x3]>
#> 8:  Sepal.Width-Petal.Length versicolor <data.table[50x3]>
#> 9:  Sepal.Width-Petal.Length  virginica <data.table[50x3]>

r2p_nest 

# Sample data
data <- data.frame(
  breed = c("A", "B", "A", "B"), 
  sex = c("F", "F", "M", "M"), 
  trait1 = c(1.1, 2.1, 3.5, 4.6),
  trait2 = c(5.2, 6.6, 7.3, 8.6))
data
#>   breed sex trait1 trait2
#> 1     A   F    1.1    5.2
#> 2     B   F    2.1    6.6
#> 3     A   M    3.5    7.3
#> 4     B   M    4.6    8.6
# Method 1: Using r2p_nest() with data.table
# Combine by breed, grouping traits
r2p_nest(data, rows2bind = "breed", by = "trait1")
#>      name              data
#>    <fctr>            <list>
#> 1: trait1 <data.table[4x4]>
# Return as data frame nested structure
r2p_nest(data, rows2bind = "breed", by = c("trait1", "trait2"), nest_type = "df")
#>      name              data
#>    <fctr>            <list>
#> 1: trait1 <data.frame[4x4]>
#> 2: trait2 <data.frame[4x4]>
# Method 2: Using tidyr and dplyr for similar transformation
data |>
  tidyr::pivot_longer(cols = c("trait1"), names_to = "name", values_to = "value") |>
  tidyr::pivot_wider(names_from = "breed", values_from = "value") |>
  dplyr::group_nest(name)
#> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 2
#>   name                 data
#>   <chr>  <list<tibble[,4]>>
#> 1 trait1            [4 Ã— 4]

export_nest 

# Data Nesting Operation
dt_nest <- w2l_nest(data = iris, cols2l = 1:2, by = "Species")
# Export Nested Data
export_nest(nest_dt = dt_nest, nest_col = "data",
            group_cols = c("name", "Species"))
#> [1] 6
# Check Export Results
files <- list.files(path = tempdir(), pattern = "txt", recursive = TRUE, full.names = TRUE)
files
#> [1] "/tmp/Rtmph9W3j6/Sepal.Length/setosa/data.txt"    
#> [2] "/tmp/Rtmph9W3j6/Sepal.Length/versicolor/data.txt"
#> [3] "/tmp/Rtmph9W3j6/Sepal.Length/virginica/data.txt" 
#> [4] "/tmp/Rtmph9W3j6/Sepal.Width/setosa/data.txt"     
#> [5] "/tmp/Rtmph9W3j6/Sepal.Width/versicolor/data.txt" 
#> [6] "/tmp/Rtmph9W3j6/Sepal.Width/virginica/data.txt"
file.remove(files)
#> [1] TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE

export_list 

# Data Nesting Operation
dt_split <- w2l_split(data = iris, cols2l = 1:2, by = "Species")
# Export Nested Data
export_list(split_dt = dt_split)
#> [1] 6
# Check Export Results
files <- list.files(path = tempdir(), pattern = "txt", recursive = TRUE, full.names = TRUE)
files
#> [1] "/tmp/Rtmph9W3j6/Sepal.Length_setosa.txt"    
#> [2] "/tmp/Rtmph9W3j6/Sepal.Length_versicolor.txt"
#> [3] "/tmp/Rtmph9W3j6/Sepal.Length_virginica.txt" 
#> [4] "/tmp/Rtmph9W3j6/Sepal.Width_setosa.txt"     
#> [5] "/tmp/Rtmph9W3j6/Sepal.Width_versicolor.txt" 
#> [6] "/tmp/Rtmph9W3j6/Sepal.Width_virginica.txt"
file.remove(files)
#> [1] TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE

convert_nest 

# Convert a data frame with nested columns to data table
df_nest1 <- iris |> 
  dplyr::group_nest(Species)
df_nest1
#> # A tibble: 3 Ã— 2
#>   Species                  data
#>   <fct>      <list<tibble[,4]>>
#> 1 setosa               [50 Ã— 4]
#> 2 versicolor           [50 Ã— 4]
#> 3 virginica            [50 Ã— 4]
df_nest2 <- iris |>
  dplyr::group_nest(Species) |>
  dplyr::mutate(data2 = purrr::map(data, dplyr::mutate, c=2))
df_nest2
#> # A tibble: 3 Ã— 3
#>   Species                  data data2            
#>   <fct>      <list<tibble[,4]>> <list>           
#> 1 setosa               [50 Ã— 4] <tibble [50 Ã— 5]>
#> 2 versicolor           [50 Ã— 4] <tibble [50 Ã— 5]>
#> 3 virginica            [50 Ã— 4] <tibble [50 Ã— 5]>
# Convert a data table with specific nested columns to data frame
convert_nest(df_nest1, to = "dt", nest_cols = c("data"))
#>       Species               data
#>        <fctr>             <list>
#> 1:     setosa <data.table[50x4]>
#> 2: versicolor <data.table[50x4]>
#> 3:  virginica <data.table[50x4]>
convert_nest(df_nest2, to = "dt", nest_cols = c("data", "data2"))
#>       Species               data              data2
#>        <fctr>             <list>             <list>
#> 1:     setosa <data.table[50x4]> <data.table[50x5]>
#> 2: versicolor <data.table[50x4]> <data.table[50x5]>
#> 3:  virginica <data.table[50x4]> <data.table[50x5]>
# Convert a data table with nested columns to data frame
dt_nest <- mintyr::w2l_nest(data = iris, cols2l = 1:2, by = "Species")
convert_nest(dt_nest, to = "df", nest_cols = c("data"))
#> # A tibble: 6 Ã— 3
#>   name         Species    data             
#>   <fct>        <fct>      <list>           
#> 1 Sepal.Length setosa     <tibble [50 Ã— 3]>
#> 2 Sepal.Length versicolor <tibble [50 Ã— 3]>
#> 3 Sepal.Length virginica  <tibble [50 Ã— 3]>
#> 4 Sepal.Width  setosa     <tibble [50 Ã— 3]>
#> 5 Sepal.Width  versicolor <tibble [50 Ã— 3]>
#> 6 Sepal.Width  virginica  <tibble [50 Ã— 3]>

get_path_segment 

# Example usage demonstrations
paths <- c("/home/user/documents", "/var/log/system", "/usr/local/bin")
# Positive index example
get_path_segment(paths, 2)
#> [1] "user"  "log"   "local"
# Negative index example
get_path_segment(paths, -2)
#> [1] "user"  "log"   "local"

format_digits 

# Create example data
dt <- data.table::data.table(
  a = c(0.1234, 0.5678),
  b = c(0.2345, 0.6789),
  c = c("text1", "text2")
)
dt
#>         a      b      c
#>     <num>  <num> <char>
#> 1: 0.1234 0.2345  text1
#> 2: 0.5678 0.6789  text2
# Format without percentage
format_digits(dt, cols = c("a", "b"))
#>         a      b      c
#>    <char> <char> <char>
#> 1:   0.12   0.23  text1
#> 2:   0.57   0.68  text2
# Format with percentage
format_digits(dt, cols = c("a"), percentage = TRUE)
#>         a      b      c
#>    <char>  <num> <char>
#> 1: 12.34% 0.2345  text1
#> 2: 56.78% 0.6789  text2

get_filename 

xlsx_files <- mintyr_example(mintyr_examples("xlsx_test"))
xlsx_files
#> [1] "/home/runner/work/_temp/Library/mintyr/extdata/xlsx_test1.xlsx"
#> [2] "/home/runner/work/_temp/Library/mintyr/extdata/xlsx_test2.xlsx"
get_filename(xlsx_files) # Keep only file names
#> [1] "xlsx_test1" "xlsx_test2"
get_filename(xlsx_files, rm_extension = FALSE) # Keep extension
#> [1] "xlsx_test1.xlsx" "xlsx_test2.xlsx"
get_filename(xlsx_files, rm_path = FALSE) # Keep path
#> [1] "/home/runner/work/_temp/Library/mintyr/extdata/xlsx_test1"
#> [2] "/home/runner/work/_temp/Library/mintyr/extdata/xlsx_test2"

w2l_nest 

w2l_nest(data = iris, cols2l = 1:4)
#>            name                data
#>          <fctr>              <list>
#> 1: Sepal.Length <data.table[150x2]>
#> 2:  Sepal.Width <data.table[150x2]>
#> 3: Petal.Length <data.table[150x2]>
#> 4:  Petal.Width <data.table[150x2]>
w2l_nest(data = iris, cols2l = c("Sepal.Length", "Sepal.Width", "Petal.Length"), by = "Species")
#>            name    Species               data
#>          <fctr>     <fctr>             <list>
#> 1: Sepal.Length     setosa <data.table[50x2]>
#> 2: Sepal.Length versicolor <data.table[50x2]>
#> 3: Sepal.Length  virginica <data.table[50x2]>
#> 4:  Sepal.Width     setosa <data.table[50x2]>
#> 5:  Sepal.Width versicolor <data.table[50x2]>
#> 6:  Sepal.Width  virginica <data.table[50x2]>
#> 7: Petal.Length     setosa <data.table[50x2]>
#> 8: Petal.Length versicolor <data.table[50x2]>
#> 9: Petal.Length  virginica <data.table[50x2]>

w2l_split 

w2l_split(data = iris, cols2l = 1:3)
#> $Sepal.Length
#>      Petal.Width   Species value
#>            <num>    <fctr> <num>
#>   1:         0.2    setosa   5.1
#>   2:         0.2    setosa   4.9
#>   3:         0.2    setosa   4.7
#>   4:         0.2    setosa   4.6
#>   5:         0.2    setosa   5.0
#>  ---                            
#> 146:         2.3 virginica   6.7
#> 147:         1.9 virginica   6.3
#> 148:         2.0 virginica   6.5
#> 149:         2.3 virginica   6.2
#> 150:         1.8 virginica   5.9
#> 
#> $Sepal.Width
#>      Petal.Width   Species value
#>            <num>    <fctr> <num>
#>   1:         0.2    setosa   3.5
#>   2:         0.2    setosa   3.0
#>   3:         0.2    setosa   3.2
#>   4:         0.2    setosa   3.1
#>   5:         0.2    setosa   3.6
#>  ---                            
#> 146:         2.3 virginica   3.0
#> 147:         1.9 virginica   2.5
#> 148:         2.0 virginica   3.0
#> 149:         2.3 virginica   3.4
#> 150:         1.8 virginica   3.0
#> 
#> $Petal.Length
#>      Petal.Width   Species value
#>            <num>    <fctr> <num>
#>   1:         0.2    setosa   1.4
#>   2:         0.2    setosa   1.4
#>   3:         0.2    setosa   1.3
#>   4:         0.2    setosa   1.5
#>   5:         0.2    setosa   1.4
#>  ---                            
#> 146:         2.3 virginica   5.2
#> 147:         1.9 virginica   5.0
#> 148:         2.0 virginica   5.2
#> 149:         2.3 virginica   5.4
#> 150:         1.8 virginica   5.1
w2l_split(data = iris, cols2l = c("Sepal.Length", "Sepal.Width"))
#> $Sepal.Length
#>      Petal.Length Petal.Width   Species value

nest_cv 

dt_nest <- w2l_nest(data = iris, cols2l = 1:2, by = "Species")
nest_cv(nest_dt = dt_nest, v = 2, repeats = 2)
#>             name    Species                    splits      id    id2
#>           <fctr>     <fctr>                    <list>  <char> <char>

top_perc 

# Example 1: Basic usage with single trait
# This example selects the top 10% of observations based on Petal.Width
# keep_data=TRUE returns both summary statistics and the filtered data
top_perc(iris, 
         perc = 0.1,                # Select top 10%
         trait = c("Petal.Width"),  # Column to analyze
         keep_data = TRUE)          # Return both stats and filtered data
#> $Petal.Width_0.1
#> $Petal.Width_0.1$stat
#> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 5
#>   variable        n  mean    sd top_perc
#>   <fct>       <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>   
#> 1 Petal.Width    17  2.34   0.1 10%     
#> 
#> $Petal.Width_0.1$data
#>    Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width   Species
#> 1           6.3         3.3          6.0         2.5 virginica
#> 2           6.5         3.0          5.8         2.2 virginica
#> 3           7.2         3.6          6.1         2.5 virginica
#> 4           5.8         2.8          5.1         2.4 virginica
#> 5           6.4         3.2          5.3         2.3 virginica
#> 6           7.7         3.8          6.7         2.2 virginica
#> 7           7.7         2.6          6.9         2.3 virginica
#> 8           6.9         3.2          5.7         2.3 virginica
#> 9           6.4         2.8          5.6         2.2 virginica
#> 10          7.7         3.0          6.1         2.3 virginica
#> 11          6.3         3.4          5.6         2.4 virginica
#> 12          6.7         3.1          5.6         2.4 virginica
#> 13          6.9         3.1          5.1         2.3 virginica
#> 14          6.8         3.2          5.9         2.3 virginica
#> 15          6.7         3.3          5.7         2.5 virginica
#> 16          6.7         3.0          5.2         2.3 virginica
#> 17          6.2         3.4          5.4         2.3 virginica

# Example 2: Using grouping with 'by' parameter
# This example performs the same analysis but separately for each Species
# Returns nested list with stats and filtered data for each group
top_perc(iris, 
         perc = 0.1,                # Select top 10%
         trait = c("Petal.Width"),  # Column to analyze
         by = "Species")            # Group by Species
#> # A tibble: 3 Ã— 6
#>   Species    variable        n  mean    sd top_perc
#>   <fct>      <fct>       <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>   
#> 1 setosa     Petal.Width     9 0.433 0.071 10%     
#> 2 versicolor Petal.Width     5 1.66  0.089 10%     
#> 3 virginica  Petal.Width     6 2.45  0.055 10%

# Example 3: Complex example with multiple percentages and grouping variables
# Uses pipe operator and transformed data
iris |>
  # Reshape data from wide to long format for Sepal.Length and Sepal.Width
  tidyr::pivot_longer(1:2,                  # Transform first two columns
                     names_to = "names",     # New column for original column names
                     values_to = "values") |># New column for values
  # Apply top_perc function on reshaped data
  mintyr::top_perc(
    perc = c(0.1, -0.2),           # Select top 10% AND bottom 20%
    trait = "values",               # Analyze the 'values' column
    by = c("Species", "names"),     # Group by both Species and measurement type
    type = "mean_sd")               # Calculate mean and standard deviation
#> # A tibble: 12 Ã— 7
#>    Species    names        variable     n  mean    sd top_perc
#>    <fct>      <chr>        <fct>    <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>   
#>  1 setosa     Sepal.Length values       5  5.64 0.134 10%     
#>  2 setosa     Sepal.Width  values       6  4.08 0.194 10%     
#>  3 versicolor Sepal.Length values       6  6.8  0.126 10%     
#>  4 versicolor Sepal.Width  values       5  3.26 0.089 10%     
#>  5 virginica  Sepal.Length values       5  7.74 0.089 10%     
#>  6 virginica  Sepal.Width  values       5  3.6  0.2   10%     
#>  7 setosa     Sepal.Length values      11  4.53 0.135 -20%    
#>  8 setosa     Sepal.Width  values      12  2.97 0.219 -20%    
#>  9 versicolor Sepal.Length values      11  5.28 0.244 -20%    
#> 10 versicolor Sepal.Width  values      13  2.35 0.151 -20%    
#> 11 virginica  Sepal.Length values      11  5.79 0.336 -20%    
#> 12 virginica  Sepal.Width  values      11  2.56 0.15  -20%
